instruction:
1. Grease the parchment with softened butter.
2. Combine the chopped chocolate and _ cup (30 g) of cocoa powder in a measuring cup or medium bowl and set aside.
3. Add the butter to a small pan over medium heat and cook until the butter just comes to a vigorous simmer, swirling the pan occasionally.
4. Immediately pour the hot butter over the chocolate mixture and let sit for 2 minutes.
5. Whisk until the chocolate is completely smooth and melted, then set aside.
6. Combine the granulated sugar, brown sugar, vanilla extract, salt, and eggs in a large bowl.
7. Beat with an electric hand mixer on high speed until light and fluffy, about 10 minutes.
8. With the mixer on, pour in the slightly cooled chocolate and butter mixture and blend until smooth.
9. Position a rack in the middle of the oven and preheat to 350�F (180�C).
10. Sift in the flour and remaining cocoa powder and use a rubber spatula to gently fold until just combined.
11. Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan and smooth the top with a spatula. Bake until lightly puffed on top, about 20 minutes.
12. Remove the baking pan from the oven using oven mitts or kitchen towels, then lightly drop the pan on a flat surface 1-2 times until the brownies deflate slightly. Bake in 175 for 45 minutes.

1. In a large bowl, cream butter, sugar, and shortening together with a hand mixer.
2. Mix the eggs, one at a time, into the batter.
3. In a medium bowl, combine the milk, lemon extract, and vanilla extract.
4. In a separate medium bowl, whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt.
5. Alternately add the dry and wet ingredients into the batter.
6. Pour the batter equally into two greased and lightly floured loaf pans.
7. Bake in a non-preheated oven set to 350�F (180�C) for 1 hour, or until toothpick inserted comes out clean.
8. Cool for 30 minutes before slicing.
9. Serve with vanilla ice cream and berries.

1. Preheat the oven to 350�F (180�C). Grease 2 8-inch cake pans with nonstick spray and line with parchment paper.
2. Sift together the cake flour, cocoa powder, salt, and baking soda. Whisk to combine.
3. In a large bowl, cream the butter and granulated sugar together with an electric hand mixer on high speed until light, fluffy, and homogenous, about 2 minutes. Add the eggs, 1 at a time, and beat on medium speed until incorporated. Add the vanilla and beat to incorporate.
4. Add _ of the buttermilk mixture to the creamed butter and sugar. Beat on medium speed until well combined. Add dry ingredients and beat until well-combined, 1�2 minutes. Repeat with the remaining buttermilk and dry ingredients.
5. Divide the batter evenly between the prepared cake pans and smooth the tops. Bake for 40�45 minutes.
6. Once cakes have cooled, trim off the domed tops, reserving the scraps. Cut each cake in half so you have 4 even layers.
7. Spread an even layer of frosting over the cake. Place another cake layer cut-side down on top of the first layer, spreading another even layer of frosting on top. Repeat with the remaining 2 layers.
8. Frost the outside of the cake with a thick layer of frosting. Crumble the reserved cake scraps, then press into the frosting around the bottom of the cake.

1. Preheat oven to 325�F (170�C).
2. Mash bananas, then add applesauce or Greek yogurt, honey, egg, vanilla extract, and almond milk. Whisk until well combined.
3. In another bowl, mix whole wheat flour, baking soda, and salt together.
4. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and stir well.
5. Spray loaf pan with cooking spray or wipe down with oil. Pour mix into a loaf pan.
6. Bake 50-55 minutes.

1. In a large bowl, whisk together the sugars, salt, and butter until a paste forms with no lumps.
2. Whisk in the egg and vanilla, beating until light ribbons fall off the whisk and remain for a short while before falling back into the mixture.
3. Sift in the flour and baking soda, then fold the mixture with a spatula (Be careful not to overmix, which would cause the gluten in the flour to toughen resulting in cakier cookies).
4. Fold in the chocolate chunks, then chill the dough for at least 30 minutes. For a more intense toffee-like flavor and deeper color, chill the dough overnight. The longer the dough rests, the more complex its flavor will be.
5. Preheat oven to 350�F (180�C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
6. Scoop the dough with an ice-cream scoop onto a parchment paper-lined baking sheet, leaving at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space between cookies and 2 inches (5 cm) of space from the edges of the pan so that the cookies can spread evenly.
7. Bake for 12-15 minutes, until the edges have started to barely brown.

1. In a large bowl, rub together the self-raising flour and cubed butter until you form fine crumbs.
2. Mix in the sugar, baking powder, and salt, and make a well in the middle.
3. Pour in the milk and gently mix together until just combined.
4. Tip the dough onto a floured surface and knead for about a minute. Be careful not to over-knead the dough.
5. Using a round cookie cutter or the rim of a glass, cut circles into the dough that are about 1-2 inches thick.
6. Place onto a baking tray lined with parchment paper.
7. Bake for 12 minutes.
